tool.name: mash screen
tool.description: determines how well query sequences are contained within a pool of sequences.
tool.command: ln -s '$queries' queries.msh && mash screen $winner_takes_all -i $minimum_identity_to_report -v $maximum_p_value_to_report queries.msh #if str( $fastq_input.fastq_input_selector ) == "paired" '$fastq_input.fastq_input1' '$fastq_input.fastq_input2' #end if #if str( $fastq_input.fastq_input_selector ) == "paired_collection" '$fastq_input.fastq_input1.forward' '$fastq_input.fastq_input1.reverse' #end if #if str( $fastq_input.fastq_input_selector ) == "single" '$fastq_input.fastq_input' #end if > '$output'

param.name: fastq_input_selector
param.label: Single or Paired-end reads
param.help: Select between paired and single end data

param.name: fastq_input
param.label: Select a paired collection
param.help: See help section for an explanation of dataset collections

tool.help:
Description:
Determine how well query sequences are contained within a pool of sequences. The queries must be formatted as a single Mash sketch file (.msh), created with the `mash sketch` command. The <pool> files can be contigs or reads, in fasta or fastq, gzipped or not, and "-" can be given for <pool> to read from standard input. The <pool> sequences are assumed to be nucleotides, and will be 6-frame translated if the <queries> are amino acids. The output fields are [identity, shared-hashes, median-multiplicity, p-value, query-ID, query-comment], where median-multiplicity is computed for shared hashes, based on the number of observations of those hashes within the pool.
